direct_answer.text: let s be the length of one side of both shapes; since each shape consists of three sides it follows that \[P_{\text{square}}=3s,\quad P_{\text{triangle}}=3s.\]Now let t denote the measure of one angle of the equilateral triangle: then \[\cos t =\frac{a}{\lvert\vec{v}_1-\vec{v}_2\rvert} \, .\]From here, using $|\vec{v}_1|=|\vec{v}_2|=s$, simplifying, applying basic trig properties, calculating, reducing, rearranging terms results in$\begin{aligned}\left(\frac{t}{360^{\circ}}\right)\cdot\pi&=\sin^{-1}\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4\times s}\right)\\ &= \left[\dfrac{1^\circ}{2\pi}\right]\int_{}^{}\arcsin\left(\tfrac{\sqrt{3}}{4 x}\right)\,dx\\&= -\frac{1}{24}\ln\left[\cos\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\right)\right].\end{aligned}$Thus$$\theta=180

Accordingly, its perimeter would be P = 4s. Similarly, because the square shares its perimeter with the equilateral triangle, using the formula \(P_{\triangle} = 3a\) where ‘a’ signifies the edge length of the triangle, the following equality holds true due to shared parameters:\[\begin{aligned}   &4s = 3a \\   &\Rightarrow a = \frac{4}{3}s .\end{aligned}\]Given that the expression for calculating areas applies only after determining appropriate values—the subsequent procedure uses properties related to right angles within squares alongside relationships inherent to regular polygons such as said triangle,\[\begin{align*}&\text{(For Square)} &&A_{sqr} =\left(\frac{s}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^2\\&\Rightarrow A_{sqr} = \frac{s^2}{2}\\& \text{(For Triangle)}\ && A_\triangle = \left(\frac{a\sin(60°)}{\sqrt{3}} \times 3\right)= (\frac{4}{3}sa)(s)\\&\Rightarrow A_\triangle = 4as.\end{align*}\]\[\begin{aligned}&=> 4a(\frac{4}{3}a)\quad\implies{}&4 * \frac{4}{3}(\frac{4}{3})^2&= 16\sqrt{3}\\&\Rightarrow {}& \frac{64}{3} &= 16\sqrt{3}\\&\Rightarrow {}& {\frac{2}{3}} &=\sqrt{3}\\&\Rightarrow {}&2 &= 3^{0.5}\end{aligned}\]\[\begin{aligned}& =>\, {(\frac{s}{\sqrt{2}})}^2&= 2 \\&\therefore \, {}& s&= \pm \sqrt{2},\end{aligned}\]wherein selecting positive solutions renders plausible geometrical figures while negative ones could create contradictions owing to dimensions being immaterial but absolute measures not so.<|end_of_document|>Hence based upon deductions garnered via algebraic processes involving squaring root expressions along with factorization techniques, thereby

direct_answer.text: To calculate the diagonal of the square, we apply the theorem relating sides and diagonals specific to squares — namely \(\sqrt{2}\) times one side equals the diagonal (`D`). With `s` representing the side length determined previously ($\sqrt{2}$ cm): \[ D = \sqrt{2} \times s \] \[\rightarrow D = \sqrt{2} \times \sqrt{2} \] \[\rightarrow D = 2 \] Henceforth, it follows logically - **The answer is:** `$2$`.
